item.title: The Colorado Civil Rights Division (CCRD) enforces...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

The Colorado Civil Rights Division (CCRD) enforces anti-discrimination laws in housing, employment, and places of public accommodation, including under Colorado's new CROWN Act. To file a discrimination complaint, visit ccrd.colorado.gov.

Colorado Department of Regulatory Agencies

The Colorado Civil Rights Division (CCRD) enforces anti-discrimination laws in housing, employment, and places of public accommodation, including under Colorado's new CROWN Act. To file a discrimination complaint, visit ccrd.colorado.gov.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "The first part of the movie features former extremists...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The first part of the movie features former extremists telling their story. And then in the middle, you focus on people who would have been folks these extremists would have victimized. Why did you want to set it up that way?
What I felt was missing was a section about how horrible it feels to be the victim of prejudice. I didn‚Äôt want to forget about the victims. So I interviewed some people from marginalized groups, including three from Colorado: State Representative Leslie Herod, [Colorado Muslim Leadership Council member] Nadeen Ibrahim, and Nicole Garcia, [the first transgender person and person of color to serve as a minister the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America]."

5280 Magazine

In "Love Wins Over Hate," Colorado filmmaker (and mother to Gov. Jared Polis) Susan Polis Schutz seeks to understand the roots of prejudice.

5280.com

Susan Polis Schutz‚Äôs New Documentary Gives a Face to Extremism

In "Love Wins Over Hate," Colorado filmmaker (and mother to Gov. Jared Polis) Susan Polis Schutz seeks to understand the roots of prejudice.In "Love Wins Over Hate," Colorado filmmaker (and mother to Gov. Jared Polis) Susan Polis Schutz seeks to understand the roots of prejudice.

item.title: "After cutting service by 40 percent way back in April...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"After cutting service by 40 percent way back in April because of the coronavirus pandemic, the Regional Transportation District has now proposed rebalancing its remaining services to favor lines where people are still riding in significant numbers.

The agency wants your feedback as it formalizes that service plan, which will take effect in January 2021. "

Colorado Public Radio

The Regional Transportation District is facing a $215 million shortfall for its 2021 budget, and it's not clear just how long these service changes will stay in place.

cpr.org

This Week, You Can Tell RTD What You Think Of Its Pandemic 2.0 Service Plan

The Regional Transportation District is facing a $215 million shortfall for its 2021 budget, and it's not clear just how long these service changes will stay in place.The Regional Transportation District is facing a $215 million shortfall for its 2021 budget, and it's not clear just how long these service changes will stay in place.

Representative Leslie Herod

Join us live to learn more about what‚Äôs on the ballot. We're starting with Prop 2A, which works to take on the climate crisis here in Denver!

Climate Action Denver was live.

An open discussion on why Denver needs Proposition 2A to pass. Our climate can't wait. Thanks to our panelists Lori Pace - Denver's Realtor, Jazmine Pace, and Harmony Cummings for making this a success.

item.title: ‚ÄúWe are finally cleaning up some of the inequities of the past...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúWe are finally cleaning up some of the inequities of the past by pardoning 2,732 convictions for Coloradans who simply had an ounce of marijuana or less," Polis said. "It‚Äôs ridiculous how being written up for smoking a joint in the 1970s has followed some Coloradans throughout their lives and gotten in the way of their success."

CBS 8 - San Diego News

The governor's office said individuals who are unsure whether a conviction on their record has been pardoned may fill out a form to request confirmation of a pardon.

cbs8.com

Gov. Polis pardons those convicted of possessing 1 ounce or less of marijuana

The governor's office said individuals who are unsure whether a conviction on their record has been pardoned may fill out a form to request confirmation of a pardon.The governor's office said individuals who are unsure whether a conviction on their record has been pardoned may fill out a form to request confirmation of a pardon.

item.title: "Colorado‚Äôs mail-in voting system sharply reduces the...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Colorado‚Äôs mail-in voting system sharply reduces the chances of mass voter intimidation schemes, Weiser said. And so far, there haven‚Äôt been any rumblings about organized efforts to do so.

But Weiser said he‚Äôll be watching.

‚ÄúIt is a crime. It‚Äôs a crime to take seriously,‚Äù Weiser told The Denver Post."

...

The Denver Post

item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúWhen McAuliffe shared its hybrid learning plan with parents...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúWhen McAuliffe shared its hybrid learning plan with parents on back-to-school night September 17, the limits of learning during Covid became clear to many who had fantasized about a return to the traditional school day. Students will return to school, but mandates from Denver Health and the district restrict how learning can take place. At McAuliffe, cohorts of 35 will engage in face-to-face learning with a teacher for only one class each day. The rest of the day, students will learn remotely, in the company of their cohort and an educator to keep them on track.‚Äù

Front Porch Newspaper

When McAuliffe shared its hybrid learning plan with parents on back-to-school night September 17, the limits of learning during Covid became clear to many who had fantasized about a return to the traditional school day.

frontporchne.com

Back-to-School Pandemic-Style | Front Porch

item.title: ‚ÄúIt took nine months in 2020 for Denver to match the number of...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúIt took nine months in 2020 for Denver to match the number of fatal drug overdoses from all of last year.

City data shows the majority of drug deaths involve multiple substances, with 60 percent of deaths involving three or more drugs and 19 percent involving five or more. The increase in deaths locally has been fueled by fentanyl, a powerful synthetic opioid that can be up to 50 times stronger than heroin.‚Äù

Denverite

A spike in fentanyl use and a pandemic has led to an increase, while overdoses nationwide have spiked.

denverite.com

Denver is on pace for a record number of fatal drug overdoses

A spike in fentanyl use and a pandemic has led to an increase, while overdoses nationwide have spiked.A spike in fentanyl use and a pandemic has led to an increase, while overdoses nationwide have spiked.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúOver the summer, the state passed several reform packages...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúOver the summer, the state passed several reform packages including mandatory body cameras for every officer in the state, an end to qualified immunity, allowing people to sue officers as individuals for up to $25,000 and a ban on chokeholds. Colorado Rep. Leslie Herod, a Democrat, told ABC News that her colleagues on both sides of the aisle wanted to address the public's concerns.‚Äù

KMBZ

By JP KEENAN and IVAN PEREIRA, ABC News

radio.com

Advocates push for police reform after summer of unrest

By JP KEENAN and IVAN PEREIRA, ABC NewsBy JP KEENAN and IVAN PEREIRA, ABC News
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúDenverites are doing a good job at filling out their Census...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúDenverites are doing a good job at filling out their Census with an extra congressional seat at stake while Colorado as a whole lags behind other states, according to data from the United States Census Bureau.

Denver ranks at sixth among large cities in terms of ‚Äúself-response.‚Äù That‚Äôs when people answer Census questions by mail, phone or internet without being nudged by Census workers. Those households account for about 69 percent of all responses, according to the most recent available data.‚Äù

Denverite

A judge just gave residents through the end of October to get counted.

denverite.com

How Denver and Colorado are doing with the census so far

A judge just gave residents through the end of October to get counted.A judge just gave residents through the end of October to get counted.

item.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.‚Äù
